abstract.text: Learn about important changes to UIKit.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Browse notable changes in
Leverage automatic trait usage tracking inside key update methods such as
, eliminating the need for manual trait change registration and invalidation.
Add repeat, wiggle, breathe, and rotate effects to
Take advantage of enhancements to
, which now automatically updates to match the style of the containing list by using the new
trait from the trait collection, removing the need to instantiate a configuration for a specific list style yourself.
Opt out or restrict collaboration on certain types of data through the share sheet using
Select a specific week of the year in
using the new
selection option.
Observe, participate in, and affect the UI update process using
Showcase your app and its unique identity with a new, customizable launch design for document-based apps. In UIKit, define
on your
Make your app’s navigation more immersive by adopting the new tab bar on iPad. If your app presents a rich hierarchy of tab items, set the
to
to automatically switch between the tab bar and sidebar representations. In SwiftUI, use
Transition between views in a way that feels fluid and consistent using a systemwide zoom transition. In UIKit, configure your view controller’s
to
. In SwiftUI, use
Use SwiftUI animations from AppKit and UIKit to create a consistent animation experience across apps that use multiple UI frameworks. In UIKit, use
. In AppKit, use
Reuse existing UIKit gesture recognizer code in SwiftUI. In SwiftUI, create UIKit gesture recognizers using
. In UIKit, refer to SwiftUI gestures by name using
Support more varieties of list layouts by configuring whether section headers stretch to fill the entire width of the list or shrink to tightly hug their content. For collection views, use
on
. For table views, use
on
Animate SF Symbols on visionOS using the symbol effects API and
Apply hierarchical vibrant text color to labels using
Specify an action to perform without shifting the focus away from the keyboard using
Push a new scene in place of an existing scene using
. The new scene appears in the same position as the original scene, hiding it. Closing the new scene makes the original scene reappear.
Create a unifying color theme in your app by specifying an accent color in your app’s asset catalog, which is now supported in tvOS.
Preview your views and view controllers alongside your code using the new
Swift macro.
Take advantage of a new view controller appearance callback,

, to run code that depends on the view’s initial geometry. The system calls this method when both the view and view controller have an up-to-date trait collection, and after the superview adds the view to the hierarchy and lays it out. This method deploys back to iOS 13.

Learn about enhancements to the trait system, which let you define custom traits for your own data, quickly change trait values throughout the view hierarchy, and register for trait changes in more flexible ways. For more information, see WWDC23 session 10057:
Display and manage empty state consistently in your app with
, which provides new system standard styles and layouts for common empty states. Help people understand why no content is present, and when possible, provide guidance on how to add content.

Create a powerful text experience in your app. Define richer interactions by changing the default tap or menu behavior when interacting with a text item. If you implement a custom UI for displaying text, support the redesigned text cursor by adopting the new text selection UI. Mark up text fields with additional text content types to help people fill out forms even faster. For more information, see WWDC23 session 10058:
Let people drop supported files and content onto your app icon on the Home Screen to open them in your app. To make sure your app is properly configured, verify that your
file specifies the file types your app supports using

Simplify how you maintain your accessibility code with block-based setters for accessibility attributes. Make sure people receive the most important information first by specifying a default, low, or high priority for announcements. Enhance custom accessibility elements with the new toggle and zoom accessibility traits.

Create a great text experience for international users by testing your UI in all languages. Adopt text styles to take advantage of enhancements to the font system, like improved wrapping and hyphenation for Chinese, German, Japanese, and Korean, as well as enhancements for variable line heights that improve legibility in several languages, including Arabic, Hindi, Thai, and Vietnamese. Access localized variants of symbol images by specifying a locale.

Help people customize their Stage Manager configuration by including a larger target area for dragging windows. Leverage new resizing behavior for split view controllers to get the most out of your UI in Stage Manager.
Support scrolling of your scroll view content with hardware keyboard shortcuts. This behavior is enabled by default, which you can override using
Simplify document management in your document-centric apps. Set your
subclass as the rename delegate of a navigation item to handle file renaming automatically. Build your content view controller from

, which provides a system default experience for managing documents: automatically configuring the title menu, sharing, drag and drop, key commands, and more. For more information, see WWDC23 session 10056:
Enhance the Apple Pencil experience in your iPadOS app. Give your app a sense of depth by using
to draw a preview of the stroke. Support the beautiful new inks in PencilKit, including monoline, fountain pen, watercolor, and crayon.
Animate symbol images with new symbol effects, including bounce, pulse, variable color, scale, appear, disappear, and replace.
Build even more performant apps with flexible layouts using collection views. Apply diffable data source snapshots and perform batch updates with even better performance. Use the
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/uikit/nscollectionlayoutdimension/4173072-uniformacrosssiblings
dimension for compositional layouts to specify uniform size across sibling items, with smaller items increasing in size to match their largest sibling.
Simplify spring animations by providing duration and bounce parameters for the new view animation method,
Represent fractional progress through a page of content with page controls.
Display and manipulate high dynamic range (HDR) images.
Display your menu as a palette with
for it to appear as a row of menu elements for choosing from a collection of items.
Take advantage of the
status bar style, which now automatically chooses a light or dark appearance that maintains contrast with the content underneath it.

Apple-Intelligence-updates-page-PageImag.alt: A stylistic image of the Apple Intelligence logo.

abstract.text: View major documentation updates and highlights from WWDC, browse ongoing updates from a set of framework releases over time, and jump to the latest release notes.
Learn about important changes to ARKit.
Learn about important changes to AVFAudio.
Learn about important changes to AVFoundation.
Learn about important changes to Accelerate.
Learn about important changes to Accessibility.
Learn about important changes in ActivityKit.
Learn about important changes to AdAttributionKit.
Learn about important changes in App Intents.
Learn about important changes to AppKit.
Learn about important changes to Apple Intelligence.
Learn about important changes to Apple Pencil.
Learn about important changes to Audio Toolbox.
Learn about important changes to AuthenticationServices.
Learn about important changes to Bundle Resources.
Learn about important changes to ContactsUI.
Animates changes to one or more views using the specified SwiftUI animation.
The document types supported by the bundle.
A navigation transition that zooms the appearing view from a given source view.
A tab bar style that adapts to each platform.
A wrapper for a `UIGestureRecognizer` that you use to integrate that gesture recognizer into your SwiftUI hierarchy.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A value that defines how the system shares an item.
An object that tracks a specific week a person selects from a calendar view.
A view that displays a calendar with date-specific decorations, and provides for user selection of a single date or multiple dates.
A configuration for creating a list layout.
A setting that determines which type of items tightly hug their content.
A type that indicates the prominence of a color in the interface.
A content configuration for a content-unavailable view.
A view controller that manages and presents a document stored locally or in the cloud.
Options that customize a document-based app’s launch view.
The unique name of the gesture recognizer.
A continuous gesture recognizer that interprets pointer movement over a view.
A view that displays a single image or a sequence of animated images in your interface.
A content configuration for a list-based content view.
Constants that indicate the style of the containing list in a collection view or table view.
An option indicating the menu displays as a row of menu elements for choosing from a collection of items.
A Boolean value that determines whether the scroll view allows scrolling its content with hardware keyboard input.
A style that automatically selects an appearance for the status bar and updates it dynamically to maintain contrast with the content below it.
The system displays the content as either a tab bar or a sidebar, depending on the context.
The display mode for a tab bar.
A view that presents data using rows in a single column.
A setting that determines which type of items tightly hug their content.
A button that appears next to the text preview in the keyboard in visionOS.
An object you use to observe, participate in, and affect the UI update process.
Animates changes to one or more views using a spring animation with the specified duration, bounce, initial velocity, delay, options, and completion handler.
Animates changes to one or more views using the specified SwiftUI animation.
Lays out subviews.
Creates a zoom transition from the view that the source provider specifies.
An object that defines the transition animation when switching to the view controller.
Notifies the view controller that the system is adding the view controller’s view to a view hierarchy.
A placement that indicates the system needs to present the window by pushing it onto another window.
